div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7356] ALEXANDRIA, MONDAY, NOVEMBER 27, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p: This Company's system of submarine telegraph cables is the most direct and quickest means of communication from Egypt to Europe, North and South America, East, South and West Africa, India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.
To secure quick transmission, telegrams should be marked Via Eastern.
For latest average time to London, see daily bulletin in this paper.
STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo, Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Said, Suakin. Head Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Office of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibralter, Plymouth, and London are inteded to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the INdian Mails arrive Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is £22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
The Sea fares are:-
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,600 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST.

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombey every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: GREECE - TURKEY LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

div.head: PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.
div.p: Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

div.head: RED SEA LINE.
div.p: Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency. 31-12-904

Express Service.- Steamers leave Cairo every Monday and Friday for Luxor, Assuan and Philae. 19 days on the Nile for £22.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste.

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for express to Paris, London, Naples, Rome. Arrival Trieste Wednesday noon connecting with Vienna Express (Trieste-Ostende through carriage) and expresses to Italy and Germany.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste
Steamers leave Alexandria on or about 22 November, 6 & 20 December.

(Departures from Suez) To Aden, Bombay, Colombo, Penang, Singapore, Hong-Kong, Shanghai, Yokohama, Kobé about December 5. div.head: INSTITUTE OF MASSAGE
div.p: As practiced in the Faculty of the Royal University of Berlin. Under the management of Sister H. Zandt.
Telephone No. 667. Alexandria: 9, Rue Toussoun Pasha.
Consultation: 7-12 a.m. for ladies and children, 2-5 p.m. for gentlemen.
Following Maladies are treated:
Diseases of Abdonimal Organs: Dyspepsis, Catarrh, Dilatation of stomach, Diarrhea, etc.
Affection of the nervous system and their complications: Anaesthesia, Hyperesthesis, Neuralgia, Neurasthenia, Paralysis, Insomnia, Sciatica, etc.
Constitutional Diseases: Araemia, Obesity, Gout, Diabetes, etc.
Diseases of the Muscles: Contracture, Rheuma- tisms, Contusions (bruise), Atrophies, etc.
Diseases of joints and bones: Arthritis, Dis- articulations, Sprains, Fractures, Ankyloses, etc.
Special diseases of women: Abdominal fix- ations and Displacement of the Genital Organs.
Deviations of the vertebral column: Scoliosis, Hunch-back, ______, etc.
Cosmetic massage: Beautifying the face and body. Wrinkles, enlarged pores and all facial blemished removed.
Vibratory and Thure-Brandt massage.
Electricy in all its forms.

div.head: Hotel Beau-Rivage.
div.p: Ramleh-Alexandria
15 Minutes by Carriage or "Palais tram from Sidi Gaber Station.
The most charming Sea-side Residence in Egypt.
First Class Family Hotel with Every Modern Comfort.
Unique Situation on the Beach.
Lovely Garden. Lawn Tennis. Large Terrace. Electric Light. Sea Baths. Own springs. Perfect sanitary arrangements. Stables for horses and carriages.
Moderate Charges. -- Special terms for Government Officials and Officers of the Army of Occupation.
G. RUNCKEWITZ, Proprietor.

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, CAIRO
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolic. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle a manager. Handsome covered promenade verande, 8 yards long. Highest class cuisince, electric light throughout, and lifts.
English comforts, Rooms and apartments at prices to suit, every one.
For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

div.head: EASTERN EXCHANGE HOTEL, PORT SAID.
div.p: First Class Hotel. Modern in all respects.
Fire-proof, Drained to the Sea, Lifts, Electric Light, English and French Billiards, Fresh and Salt Water Baths.
The Coolest Summer Residence in Egypt.
Special terms to Cairo Residents and their families desirous of enjoying the cool air and sea bathing during the summer months.
Dragomans in Hotel Uniform Meet all Trains and Steamers.

div.head: IMPORTANT NOTICE.
MARTELL COGNAC.
div.p: M. H. DEMIRGIAN BEY, General Agent for this important House, warns the public to beware of Imitations, and to examine the labels, corks, and capsules.
The principal importers of this well-known Brand are
At Alexandria: MM. G. Attard & Co. Christo C. Solea, Costi H. Georgiou, N. Pappa, A. & G. Monferato, John B. Caffari, Frangini Mitzos & Co. Cokinos Freres, P, J. Zombos.
At Cairo: MM. S. di M. Riso, A. Jeronymidis & John B.Caffari.

div.head: MAGASINS VICTORIA.
div.p: ECCLESTONE AND KEILL ENGLISH DRAPERY.
Opposite Austrian Consulate, near the Zizinia Theatre. Catalogue on application.

div.head: NOTICE
div.p: Merchants, Tradesman and others in Cairo wishing to do business with British firms are requested to send their names, addresses and particulars of their business to Mr. Peter Blank, "The Commercial Bureau," P.O. Box No. 50, Cairo.

row.cell: Season for navigation in the Indian Ocean.
Avoid voyaging in the Mediterra- nean Sea.
Food taken from the water is recommended.
Abu dance of the clouds. The close of night is cold.
Ripening of chestnuts. Appearance of winter vegetables.
Disturbance of the bile. Avoid drinking water at night.

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: The weather remains pleasantly cool. There is less dampness, the morning opened with a S.W. wind and the barometer falling.

table.head: OTHER STATIONS.
For the 24 hours ending 3 a.m. Yesterday

div.head: SUBSCRIPTIONS.
div.p: Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber's address) P.T. 231 1/2 per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six motnhs P.T. 136 1/2 (£1.8s), three months P.T. 95 (0.19s.).
H.H.- Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

div.head: ADVERTISEMENTS.
div.p: P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages or Deaths, not axceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news collumn P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.

div.head: SUBSCRIPTIONS and ADVERTISEMENTS
div.p: are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, ROWLAND SNELLING, Alexandria.
London Offices- 36, New Broad Street, E.C.
The Egyptian Gazette can be obtained in London at our offices, 36, New Broad Street, E.C., and also at Messrs MAY & WILLIAMS, 160 Piccadilly, W.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: The English daily paper, establshed 1888.
Editor and Manager - - R. Shellire
Price: One Piastre Tariff.

div.head: LIBERAL SPLIT. THE HOME RULE BANNER SENSATIONAL SPEECH BY LORD ROSEBERY.
div.p: Speaking at Bodmin yesterday evening, Lord Rosebery said that, n once more hoisting the banner of Home Rule, and that in the most pronounced form, Sir Henry Campbell- Bannerman is impairing the unity of the Free Trade party, upon which victory at the elections depends. He would say emphatically, explicitly, and once for all, "I cannot serve under that banner." This speech has caused a sensation in political circles.

Lord Rosebery's remarks have caused the utmost surprise in Liberal circles, recent speeches of his having led to the supposition that he fully intended to co-operate with Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman.
(Reuter)

div.head: DATE OF DISSOLUTION. PROBABLY IN JANUARY.
div.p: The general consenses of opinion is that the dissolution will take place early in January. It is uncertain whether the Government will in the meantime resign.
(Reuter)
The warships of the Powers left at midday with sailed orders.
(Havas)
The international fleet has sailed with sealed orders.
(Reuter)
The Ambassadors have decided to persist in the demonstration. The populations is calm, but it is unaware of the situation.
(Havas)
Tewfik Pasha has asked the British and Austrian Ambassadors to modify the Mace- donian project of reforms.
(Havas)
The International Squadron is expected to arrive at Mitylene this morning.
(Reuter)
King Hakon and Queen Maud have made their ceremonial entry. They were acclaimed by a hundred thousand persons.
(Reuter)
King Hakon and his family have arrived. They received an enthusiastic welcome.
(Havas)

div.head: RACING.
div.p: Manchester Handicap, 1 Ferment; 2 Ima- ri; 3 Spinning Minnow. Betting 25 to 1 against Ferment; 25 to 1 against Imari; 100 to 12 against Spinning Minnow. 19 ran. Won by three lengths, three quarters of a length dividng the second and third.
(Reuter)

div.head: FOOTBALL.
div.p: The New Zealanders beat Ireland by 15 to 0.
(Reuter)

div.head: RISINGS AND STRIKES. MUTINY AT SEVASTOPOL. AN ADMIRABLE SHOT.

div.p: Reports from the provinces show that serious risings of peasants in many country districts, and of strikers in the towns, continue. The employes here are enforcing a combined lock- out because the workmen were practically taking 8 hours per diem work.
The results of the congress of Zemstvos appears to be that there is little chance of the chiefs of the liberal party co-operating with M. Witte.
The lock-out is rapidly assuming a general character.

The sailors and a regiment of troops have mutinied. Rear Admiral Pessrevaki was shot and seriously wounded while haranguing the men, whom he threatened to have shot down by the troops. The mutineers have ordered the Admiral in Chief to leave in three days. The dockers have joined the mutineers and serious rioting has taking place.
(Reuter)

An official communique ascribes the mutiny at Sevastopol to the Socialist propoganda. The gravity of the situation is admitted, though it is not expected that looting and plundering will take place. It is rumoured that the disaffec- tion is spreading among the naval battalions here.

The most serious feature of the mutiny at Sevastopol is the wholesale detection of the troops, who apparently made common cause with the mutineers. Only one regiment remains loyal. Up to the present there have been no excesses. The silence of the offi- cial communique as to measure for the repression of the mutiny is regarded as confirming the rumour that the warships are in the hands of the mutineers. The revolt has been carefully prepared, and deliberately carried out.
The Council of Ministers have approved the proposal to grant 15,000,000 roubles to im- prove the condition of the railway men.
(Reuter)
The strike is spreading and strikers are looting indiscriminately.
(Reuter)
The sailors have mutinied. Admiral Pesa- revaki has been wounded and an officer kill- ed. The mutiny has partly spread to the gar- rison. They have commenced to pillage the town.
(Havas)

A Ukase abolishes the posts of Governor General of this city, chief of police and gen- darmerie of the Empire, and Assistant Min- ister of the Interior, all of which were held by General Trepoff. A civilian will be appointed director of the police department.
(Reuter)

div.head: SIR C. HARDINGE'S SUCCESSOR.
div.p: London, November 25.
Sir A. Nichelson, at present Ambassador at Madrid, succeeds Sir C. Hardinge at St. Peters- burg.
(Reuter)

div.head: PASSENGER LIST. ARRIVALS.
div.p: Per S.S. Cleopatra of the Austrian Lloyd, arrived this morning from Trieste and Brindisi:

M. Denfler, M. Kantzky, Mme Heller, Mrs. Barkow, M. Stein, M. Terel, Mr. Stern, Count and Countess Komkrin, Mme Grenzel, Mme Baldouin, Mme Harari and family, M. Czerncy, M. Hurtig Gottfard, Mme Cassani, M. et Mme Brunn, M. Conrad Risler, M. Dufetre, M. Paul Wolfs, M. Vanucei, Mmes Salvago and Sina- dino, M. de Stsercke, Capt. Young, Mrs and Miss Mitchell, M. J. Jaouich, M. Leonhard, M. Millen, M. Kugen, Mme Klein, M. and Mme de Holtzke, M. Kerstner, M. Klodie, M and Mme Belnsck, Mlle Martin, Mlle Blosin- ger, M. Muller, M. Manersherger, M. Richter, M. Hammer, M. Eppinger, M. Giuli, M. Kowar, M. Rickeito and two of family, Mme Bratos, M., Mme and Mlle Foschiatti, M. Pantich, M. Starge, Dr. Schmield, M. Bind- schseller, M. and Mme Falk, Mme Meyer, Mme Petcovich, Mme Patzek and daughter, Gen Vukovie, M. Hold, M. Zimmermann, M Barteaux, Mr. Elton, Mme Laren, Mme Hal- back, M. and Mme Gruman, M.V. Nasch, M.A. Fodor, Oberl. W. Ed. E. Wagner Thurn- burg, M.M. Ritter von Tarnoczy, M.L.A. Levi, M. Heinrich Berger, M.R. Ritter von Albert.

Per S.S. Memfi, of the Florio Rubattino ar- rived yesterday from Genoa and Messina: Cav. P. Parvis, Cav. M. Guastalla, Mr. B. Santambrogio, Mr. A. Olivier, Mr. Szilagi, Mr. P. Murgo, Mr. Petrie, M. and Mme Cuccia, M. and Mme G. Giuseppo, M.E. Cassah, Mme R. Giovannini and daughter, Mr. P. Campoli, Mr. Gieard Smith, M.R. Dameno, M.G.N. Norry, M.L. Yelo, Mr. L.S. Stowey, M.L. Banadetti, M.D. Chiesa and 63 third class passengers.

div.head: Small Dance.
div.p: There will be a small dance at Mena House Hotel on Wednesday next, commencing at 9 p.m.

div.head: Irrigation Department.
div.p: Mr. Proud and Mr. Shane Chichester have joined the Second and Third Circles of Irriga- tion respectively as surveyors of contracts.

div.head: Alhambra Theatre.
div.p: A troupe of French artistes, fifty in number, arrived at Alexandria from Athens yesterday, and will commence a series of performances of French operettas at the Alhambra on Friday next.

div.head: Suez Canal.
div.p: Thirteen vessels passed through the Canal on the 22nd inst., of which 10 were British, 1 French, 1 Dutch, 1 Austrian. The total receipts from the 1st to the 22nd inst. were frs. 7,543,792.61.

div.head: Egyptian Money Market.
div.p: Messrs. H. de Vries and Boutigny, stock and share brokers, Cairo publish a very detailed circular daily on the business of the stock market. This circular, which contains also a great deal of financial information, is sent gratis on application. [Advt.]

div.head: Cairo Hotels.
div.p: Shepheard's and Ghezireh Palace's orchestra for the season, composed of 1 selected musicians under the direction of Ferenez Babari, a well- known "primas," will arrive on December 12. The reopening of Ghezireh Palace will take place between the 10th and 15th of December.

div.head: Cakes and Divorce.
div.p: A native contemporary declares that eleven Moslem married women have just been divorced owing to disputes with their husbands arrising about cakes for Beyram. The women in every case insisted on having these cakes made according to the usual fashion, but the husbands objected that they could not afford the ex- pense and so the marriages were dissolved.

div.head: Lottery Case.
div.p: This morning the Contravention Court of the Alexandria Mixed Tribunals gave judg- ment in the case of the "Ministere Public" r. Robert Kronfeld. The defendent was charged with sending by post noticed of the royal Hungarian Lottery. He was ordered to pay a fine of P.T. 100 and costs. The "pieces de conviction" are to be confiscated. The text of the judgment will be given in our next issue.

div.head: Charity Ball.
div.p: The ball given by the Germania Lodge on Saturday at the Khedivial Hotel, under the patronage of Baron Felix de Menasce, was a great success, the greatest harmony prevailing. The proceeds of the ball will be used for the purchase of clothing for poor children. The distribution will take place on the 10th De- cember at 3.30 p.m. in the Masonic hall "Alex- andre Le Grand," 2, Metnelli-street. The Ger- manie Ludge thanks all who have assisted them, especially the donors of gifts for the lottery, which was drawn the same evening. The amount realised by the lottery is to be devoted to assistign families of the victims of the massa- cres in Russia and will be handed over to the British Consul through Baron Felix de Manasce.
The Khedive has conferred the grade of Mirmiran upon H.H. Prince Mohamed Pasha Ibrahim, who has also received the order of the Medjidieh of the 1st class.
Prince Mohammed Ibrahim is staying at Shepheard's.
H.H. the Khedive has conferred on H.E. Ahmed Chawki Bey, his Highness's Poet Lau- reate, the grade of Oula Sinf Sani.
Sir Vincent Corbett and Mr. and Mrs. Rowlatt have arrived at Mena House Hotel, where they will spend the Beyram holiday Major Palmer, of the War Office, is expected of Wednesday next.
Sir Charles Scotter, with Mr. and Mrs. Fred Scotter, left London for Egypt last week. Sir Charles Scotter is Chairman of the London and South Western Railway.
Mr. H.E. Lawford is leaving Port Said by the Cheshire for London on business, and expects to return to Egypt early in January.
El Bimbashi L.E.M.P. Cockerell, 2nd Batta- lion, has been struck off the strength of the Egyptian Army, from 16-11-05.

Several dinner parties were given in She- pheard's restaurant on Saturday, on the occa- sion of the small dance. We noticed Mr. Mor- gan and a party of 19. Baron de Zuylen had 10 guests at his table, including Count and Coun- tess Gramallo, and Mr. and Mrs. Surcouf. Major and Mrs. Patte son had a party of 3, and Mr. McGillivray a party of 7. There were several smaller dinner parties, including those of Mr. A Willis, Col. Watson, Baron von Moltke, Baroness von Brandis, Mr. Paravicini, etc.

div.head: NOTICE.
div.p: To-morrow (Feast of Beyram), being a general holiday, the Egyptian Gazette will no be published.

div.head: 1906 BUDGET ESTIMATES. REDUCTION IN TAXATION.
div.p: The Budget Estimates submitted on Satur- day to the Council of Ministers are as follows:-
The revenue for 1905 is estimated at about L.E. 14,500,000
It is proposed to make the following reduc- tions in taxation:

row.cell: Reduction to 4% of the import duty on coal, mezat (liquid fuel), charcoal, fire- wood, timber for buildings, petroleum, oxen, cows, sheep and goats.
Abolition of the salt mono- poly, fixing the price of the salt sold by the Salt and Soda Co. at a maximum of 2 milliemes per kilgramme.
Suppression of the tax on sea fisheries.
Supression of the tax on ferry boats on the canals and reduction of the tax on the Nile ferries.
Reduction of the Red Sea lighthouse duties.

div.p: The sum of L.E. 120,000 appears in the Budget for the reorganization of the cadres. This question will be studied fromthe begin- ning of next year and the increase of pay will come into operation from January 1, 1906.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: On Saturday morning H.H. the Khedive came up from Koubbeh to Abdeen Palace and received H.H. Prince Fouad, the Marquis Salvago Raggi, (who presented Count Man- zoni). Baron von Humboldt-Dachroeden and M. Nyholm (who presented Baron Shelby and Lieut. Brammen, of the Danish guard).

At 2 p.m. his High ness presided over the Council of Ministers, and at 2.40 p.m. received the vists of the Duke of Brunswick Luneburg. At 3.30 p.m. the Khedive returned the Duke's visit at Shepheard's Hotel, being excorted by a detachment of his Bodyguard and acco- panied by H.E. Ahmed Zeki Pasha, the Grand Master of Ceremonies.

div.head: BEYRAM.
div.p: On the occasion of the feast of Beyram, the Sanior Military Office of the Egyptian Army in Cairo has directed the all officers of the \ rank of Bmbashi and upwards, no on duty, shall attend the Khedive's levee, and shall meet El Lewa Berrard Pasha, in the absence of the Sirdar, at Abdeen Palace at 9.10 a.m. tomorrow.

A guards of honor, composed of 100 non- commissioned officers and men, battalion color and infantry band, will paarde at Abdeen- square, facing the general entrance to the Palace, at 10.15 a.m. to pay the usual compli- ments to the Corps Diplomatique on their arrival.

A solute of 21 guns will be fired when his Highness leaves Koubbeh mosque, and the cus- tomary salute will be fired from the Citadel, Abbassieh, Alexandria, and Port Said, on the eve, and during the feast.

div.head: SEFI IRRIGATION.
div.p: Seeing that under existing conditions the extension of Sefi irrigation is impossible and that, generally speaking, the supply of water only exceeds the demand during a couple of the winter months, intending purchasers of agricultural land are recommended, before commencing negotiations for purchase, to sa- tisfy themselves, by enquiry from the Irriga- tion Service, as to whether a supply of water is avail;able or not for the property they pro- pose to acquire, so as to avoid subsequent disappointment.

div.head: CLOSING OF CANALS.
div.p: The Ibrahimieh Canal will be closed at Sharahnah Regulator for forty days commenc- ing from the 15th December, for the comple- tion of its enlargment from Sharahnah to its present terminal point near Ashmant.

The annual closure of canals in the 1st Circle of Irrigation will take place on the 20th December, when canals will be closed for one month for clearances. The Rayah Tewfiki will not be closed down as low as usual navigation for boats of not more than 5000 ardebs will be kept open through to Mansourah.
The Ismailia Canal will be complete closed to navigation and the tail locks at Ismailia and Syriakos lcoks will be closed.
No canals in this Circle other than Rayah Tewfiki will be opened for navigation.

div.head: MAHMOUDIEH CANAL.
div.p: From the 20th December the canals in the 3rd Circle of Irrigation will be closed, or consi- derably lowered, for about six weeks, for annual works and clearances, with the excep- tion of the Mahmoudieh Canal, which will be kept at a level sufficient for navigation only.

div.head: LORD CURZON'S VISIT. MUCH IMPROVED IN HEALTH.
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.)
div.p: As I wired you yesterday, the R.I.M.S. Dufferin arrived at Suez in the afternoon flying the Viceroy's flag. As soon as she drop- ped anchor, she was dressed with flags. The director of the Quarantine Office, accompanied by two medical officers, boarded the Dufferin on arrival and practique was given at 3 c'clock when Mr. D.A. Cameron, British Consul, welcomed Lord and Lady Curzon. Shortly afterwards the Governor of Suez, accompanied by the chief of police and others, paid his lordship an official call.

At about 5.30 p.m. Lord and Lady Curzon, accompanied by Lord Curzon's secretary (Mr. Nathan), the Governor of Suez, Mr. Cameron, and others, landed at the passport pier, and proceeded to the railway station, where a special carriage had been placed at their disposal.

The train arrived at Suez station at 5.50; a guard of honor was drawn up and saluted the distinguished visitors. H.E. the Governor of Suez presented Lady Curzon with a beautiful bouquet of flowers, and at 6 p.m. the train left the station amidst the cheers of the spectators.
Lord and Lady Curzon proceeded to Cairo, and, I understand, will join the P. & O. Mon- golia at port Said to-morrow for Marseilles.
The rest of the party remained on board the Dufferin, and will be transferred to the Mongolia at Suez to-day.
Mr. D.A. Cameron accompanied Lord and Lady Curzon as far as Ismailia.
Lord and Lady Curzon arrived at Cairo late on Saturday from Suez and immediately proceeded to the British Agency, where they are staying as guests of Lord and Lady Cromer.

Yesterday afternoon Lord Curzon went for a drive in Cairo, while those who happened to visit the Zoological Gardens in the afternoon had the pleasure of seeing Lady Cromer and Lady Curzon, looking very well. Lady Curzon looked charming in a cream gown and black picture hat.
This morning Lord and Lady Curzon visited the Pyramids, and were expected to pay a visit to the bazaars later. They will leave for Port Said by special train at about 4 p.m. to-day.
We understand that Lord Curzon, although still feeling the effects of overwork and anxiety, is in much improved health.

div.head: ROYAL VISITORS.
div.p: H.R.H. Prince Leopold of Battenberg is due to arrive at Port Said by the Ormuz on Thursday.

div.head: ARRIVAL OF BRITISH WARSHIP.
div.p: His Britannie Majesty's cruiser Carnervon, one of the newest type of cruiser built, arrived at Alexandria yesterday, flying the flag of Rear-admiral Hon. H. Lambton, C.V.O., with Captain Sir George J.S.Warrender Bart, C.B., M.V.O., in command.
The Carnervon is an armoured cruiser car- rying four 7.5" guns, six 6" two 1 pdrs, and 20 3 pdrs., having a speed of 23.3 knots.
On arrival in the port, the Carnervon exchanged the usual salutes with Fort Saleh, and anchored near Ras-el-Tin lighthouse.
Visits were afterwards paid by Mr. E.B. Gould, I.S.O., and Rear-Admiral Sir Massie Blomfield, K.C.M.G.
Rear-Admiral Lambton will make arrange- ments so that any Briths residents and their friends who wish to do so, may see over the ship on Wednesday, 29th inst., and Sunday, 3rd December.
The ship will leave in about 10 days' time.

div.head: THE FIRE ON THE SARDINIA.
div.p: The fire in the forehold of the Ellerman S.S. Sardinia was finally extinguished on Saturday night, and the fire-float returned to the Arsenal yesterday morning. The vessel was taken off the sand in the afternoon, and to-day entered the inner harbour, where she will discharge the remainder of her cargo.
It is probable that the Sardinia will be dry- docked at Alexandria.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The M.M. steamer Portugal, from Marseil- les, passed the Straights of Messine on Saturday and is due at Alexandria to-morrow.
Anglo-American Nile Steamer & Hotel Company
River Transport of Good Between Alexandria & Cairo
Three Sailings a-Week.
Agents at Alexandria:
Alexandria Bonded Warehouse Co. Ld

div.head: WINDSOR HOTEL Restaurant.
div.p: Table d’Hote Luncheons & Dinners Served on the Terrace.
DELIGHTFUL SITUATION - SEA BREEZES.

div.head: DAIRA SANIEH COMPANY. LAST STEP IN LIQUIDATION.
div.p: Last Saturday witnessed the last public act in the winding-up of the Daira Sanieh Company, Limited- the final general meeting of shareholders, called for the purpose of having an account laid before them showing the manner in which the winding-up has been conducted and the property of the company disposed of, and of hearing th explaination of the liquidators, and to determine the manner in which the books, accounts and documents of the company and of the liquida- tors should be disposed of.

The meeting was held at noon at the National Bank of Egypt, Mr. F.T. Rowlatt in the chair. There were fourteen shareholders present in person, representing a total of 645 ordinary shares, while a furhter 618 ordinary shares were represented by proxy. The comparatively small amount of captial represented was of course owing to the fact that the great bulk of the shares of La Societe Egyptienne de la Daira Sanieh, its successor.
Mr. Rowlatt made a short explanatory speech in the following terms:

Gentlemen,- This meeting has been called to comply with the requirements of the Com- panies Acts. It is the last step inthe liquida- tion of the Daira Sanieh Company,- its ob- sequies, in fact. As you are all aware, the Daira Sanieh Company, Limited (which I will call the Enlish company), by an agreement made in March last, transferred to "La Societe Egyp- tienne de la Daira Sanieh" the whole of its assets of whatsoever description, subject of course to its liabilities. In consideration of this transfer, the English company received fully-paid ordinary and deferred shares of the Egyptian company, identical in every respect with those of the English company, and to a like nominal amount. The principal duty of the liquidators consisted in giving these new shares in exchange for the share certificates and bearer warrants of the English company- share for share. This ex- change has been effected, and the shares of the English company duly cancelled, with the exception of a small number which have not yet been presented for exchange. The holders of these shares are, however, expected to come in very shortly, and, until they do so, they will of course receive no dividend. As you will all understand, this transfer from the English company to the Egyptian company did not in itself necessitate the preparation of any accounts, the operation consisting, if I may so describe it, in taking the whole concern out of one box and placing it in another- the whole of the assets of whatsoever nature after deduction of the whole of the liabilities. It was, however, necessary to prepare accounts in order to open the books of the Egyptian company. These accounts, conssiting of a balance-sheet and a profit and loss account as at 8th July last, have been audited by Messrs. Russell and Kerr, and are now placed on the table. I will not read to you the resolutions on which you are asked to vote:

1. That the explanation of the liquidators as to the method in which the liquidation has been conducted and the property of the com- pany disposed of having been received and the accounts having been submitted, the same are hereby approved and adopted.
2. That the books, accounts and documents of the company and of the liquidators thereof be forthwith handed over to La Societe Egyptienne de la Daira Sanieh.
On being put to the vote, both resolutions were carried unanimously on a show of hands.

div.head: ANGLO-AMERICAN COMPANY
div.p: With refernce to the article that appeared in our issue of last Saturday regarding the contract signed at Cairo by Mr. Stangen, local representative of the Hamburg-Amerika Line, and the directors of the Anglo-American Co., for the amalgamation of their Nile tourist services, we are now informed that to provide the necessary capital to meet the greatly in- creased traffic that is expected from this fusion the latter company has decided to issue 5,000 new shares, which the Hamburg- Amerika Line will take up at the price of £5 each, or £1 premium. Of this sum £5,000 will be added to the reserve and with the balance will be purchased two more steamers to be delivered in time for next year's season.

We are also informed that no time limit has been inserted in the contract as regards the deration of the amalgamation, which is an important point in favor of the Anglo- American Co. After the close of the current financial year, that is, on the 1st May next the name of the Hambourg-Amerika Lina will be added to that of the Anglo-American Nile Steamer and Hotel Company.

div.head: ARISTON AERATED WATERS
div.p: Guaranteed Distilled.
ALEXANDRIA: 7 Rue de la Poste.
CAIRO opposite the Tramways Co. Works, Sharia Sahal, Kasr-el-Nil

div.head: THE SUCRERIES COMPANY. MEETING OF SHAREHOLDERS.
div.p: The extraordinary general meeting of the shareholders of the Sucreries Company was held in Cairo on Saturday at 4.15 p.m. and was largely attended. M. Barois was in the chair, supported by the Hon. A.J. Davey M.M. Arbib, Naus and Naville, Me. Carton de Wiart, shareholders and avecats acting as proxies, or otherwise interested representing 52,000 add shares. Proceedings opened with the reading of the report, the text of which we give in full:-

Messieurs, nous vous avons conveques en Assemblee Generale pour vous exposer en toute sincerite la situation de la Societe et vous demander de prendre les mesures ur- gentes necessaires pour empecher la faillite qui equivaudrait pour vous, Actionnares, a une ruine complete et pour les Obligataires a une perte importante.

Nous n'avons pas a vous rappeler la mort tragiquede votre ancient President, survenue le 27 Aout et les revelations qui s'en suivi- rent? Nous apprimes l'echesnce prochaine de traites pour un montant de 24 Millions environ acceptees par deux des Administrateurs dele- gues. Il fallait eviter a tout prix les protets et la faillite, sauf a etudier ensuite de pres, les consequences de cette charge imprevue.

Sur l'avis de nos Avocats a Paris et en Egypt nous demandions a etre admis an benefice du Concordat preventif et le 19 Septembre nous obtenions un judgement auto- risant les operations preperatoires a la decla- ration du Concordat. La Juge-Commissaire nomma trois Controleurs: Sir Elwin Palmer, Gouverneur de la Banque Nationale d'Egypte et Ancient Conseiller financier du Gouverne- ment Egyptien; S.E. Harari Pacha, Directeur General de la Daira Sanieh et ancien Directeur General de la compatabilite de l'Etat; M. Eugene Debourg, Industriel Administrateur Delegue de la Salt and Soda. Il designa aussi des Experts charges d'exeminer la situation.

Eu meme temps que les Experts s'occu- perent de l'elaboration de leuf rapport, nous procedions, avec l'aide de specialistes designes par les principaux groupes de creanciers et d'interesses a l'examen des charges et des resources. Les traites dont le decouvert avait necessite le depot du bilan etaient signees a concurrance de 18 millions par un des admi- nistrateur-delegues; a concurrence de 6 mil- lions par l'autre, chacun ignorant ce que l'autre avait signe. Le troisieme Admi- ni trateur-Delegue et tous les membres du Conseil, autre que feu le President, ignoraient tout. Nous decouvrions une contre- partie de ces effects consistant en traites acceptees en blanc par la liquidation H. Say & Co Mais vis-a-vis de tous porteurs, nous etions responsables. Nos avocats ne nous laissent ancun donte a cet egard.

Ce n'etait le qu-une des phases de ce que revela la mort de M. Cronier. On reconnut alors que le groupement des resultats divers de l'industrie sociale avec des operations de commerce et d'arbitrages executees sur une grande echelle par M. Cronier, en dehors de tout controle, et reglees ensemble en fin d'exer- cice, ainsi que le fait que l'ensemble avait tou- jours donne un benefice apparent, avaient dissimule au Conseil d'Administration, comme a vous-memes, le veritable situation indus- trielle.

Nous nous sommes preoccupes de determi- ner avec precision la situation actuelle et ne croyons pourvoir mieux faire, que d'adopter le bilan dresse par Messieurs les Controleurs. Il a ete serieusement etabli en dehors des questions de personnalites et de polemiques irritantes qui interviennent trop souvent dans l'appre- ciation d'une situation comme celle ui nous a ete faite. Nous erons a meme de defendre completement ce bilan et ses bases des discus- sions de detail.

Vous avez a decider aujourd'hui s'il y a lieu de laisser declarer la faillite et liquider l'Actif dans des circonstances qui ne laissent absolu- ment rien au capital actions, ou au contraire, de tenter par une reconstitution financiere, et sous une direction sage et ecouome, de rememttre l'affaire sur pied et tout en diminuant la perts actuelle de vous donner les moyens de recupe- rer peut-etre une partie de ce qui a ete englouti.

Messieurs les Controleurs ont bien voulu se charger, en attendant que vous ayiez donne pouvoir a vos mandataires, de le faire, de trausmettre certaines propositions au Juge- Commissaire. La base essentielle est que- apres avoir traite avec les creaneiers des diverses categories, vous receviez en echange de trois actions actuelles, une action nouvelle con- courant aux resultats de l'entreprise.

D'apres l'etat desnegeciations actueilement en cours a Paris nous pouvons presumer que ce te combinaison sera maintenue de que'que feconque les porleurs des traites Cronier, les Obligataires et la Daira Sugar Corporation fixent, vis a vis les uns des autres, la maniere dont seront reglees leurs creances respectives.
Vous recevrez ulterienrement que'que de- tails sur la situation toute speciale de la Daira Sugar Corporation, resultant des contrats passes avec elle.

D'autre part les Obligataires concentiraient dans le projet objet des pourparlers actnels, une reduction de ringt pour cent sur le chiffre nominal de leurs titres ce qui constitue une perte inferieure a 20% sur les pius demission. Une reduction analoque est demandes aux porteurs des traites Cronier.

D'ailleurs c'est a titre de simple renesigne- ment que nous vous indiquons residonnees. Il ne s'agit pour le mement que de donner mandat d'obtenir si possible un concordat aux meil- eures conditions pour ves creanciere et vouer.
